div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: EGYPT AND INDIA.
div.p: The danger of newspaper sedition in India has led some of the London Press to draw a parallel between the Anglophobe Indian and and Egyptian vernacular newspaper. "The Globe" remarks :—"Too much importance may be attached to the native celebrations of the Mutiny in India, but growth is tropical in India, and we may any day find that we have cultivated to the seeding point a sedition that at present has no real root. Throughout the Punjanb, Eastern and Western Bengal, and Bombay, the native Press preaching a crusade of rebellion with the unrestrained oratory in which both native writers aud readers exult. Seditious pamphlets, compact of historical lies and present inventions, are being circulated among the people in enormous quantities ; and the burden of them all is that the people of India are being overridden by a foreign devil, who will he terrified out of the country by the first real show of force. Perhaps these midges and gnats of the native Press do no more than buzz and irritate ; but it is hardly less the duty of a proper Government to prevent petty vexations than open sedition. The peacefulness and comfort of the community, native and European, has been immensely disturbed in India, us in Egypt, by these contemptible agents of pestilence. They can serve no good purpose in the economy of the country, and in the name of commonsense and good government should be suppressed drastically and instantly. "If you mean to live," writes a Calcutta paper, "after seeing your sons, wives, and daughters, oppressed and dishonoured; then live quietly as slaves. But if not thus, oppressed Indians, avenge yourselves." We do not deserve empire if our rulers permit the publication of such pestilential nonsense. Its suppression will block no valve, and will do a world of good. At present the only actual effect of our boasted policy of tolerance is to sacrifice the progress and comfort of India to the salaries of a few vapourous journalists. Egypt, and India too, want not a "quarter of an hour of a Napoleon," but five minutes robust commonsense in a Government.

div.head: The Moore Case.
div.p: The Serghnni-Moore case will come on in appeal before the Native Court of 1st Instance at Cairo on Saturday next, the 26th inst.

div.head: The Cadis School.
div.p: The formalities for the purchase of the purchase which is to house the school for Cadis, are now complete. The new school will be opened on the 1st October.

div.head: Marsa Matrouh Markaz.
div.p: Fifteen villages have been taken from the Marsa Matrouh district in order to form the district of El Debba, where the terminus of the Khedive's Mariout line is situated.

div.head: French National Fate.
div.p: The members of the French colony at Cairo will meet to-morrow, the 24th inst., to discuss the measures to be taken for the celebration of the French National Fate on the 14th July.

div.head: Ivory Arrivals.
div.p: Eight tons Egyptian and four tons Abyssinian ivory have arrived in London to date for Quarterly Sales, commencing July 23. The deliveries since the April auctions amount to 36 tons.

div.head: A Cairo Crime.
div.p: The Court of Appeal of Ancona has sentenced Salomon Cohen, an ironmonger of Cairo, to fifteen months' imprisonment and a fine of 500 francs. Cohen killed his brother with a knife some time ago in Cairo.

div.head: Cattle Plague
div.p: During the week ending the 20th inst. 175 fatal cases of cattle plague have occurred throughout the country, of which 39 are reported from Maghagha ; 39 at Abou Zerkas ; 30 at Fashn : 23 at Beni-Mazar ; 11 at Samallout ; 2 at Minieh ; 2 at Beba ; 21 at Deirout and 8 at Mellawi.

div.head: Strike in Cairo.
div.p: A certain number of discontented silk weavers have been out on strike since Sunday last and have caused several small disturbances in the streets of Cairo. Boulac seems to be the favourite spot for their aimless demonstrations. As far as can he ascertained their demands have not yet been acceded to.

div.head: Plague.
div.p: During the past 24 hours the following cases of plague have been reported : — 1 new case and 3 declared cured at Beni-Mazar ; 1 death out of hospital at Assiout ; 1 death out of hospital at Mellawi ; 3 discharged as cured at Deirout ; 1 death in hospital at Abnoub and 1 at Esneh. 62 cases still remain under treatment.

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: 504 births were recorded in Cairo between the 14th and 20th inst of which 4 were Europeans. 601 deaths occurred during the same period of which 17 were Europeans. As regards the latter figures the following details are given 178 adults, of which 8 Europeans, and 423 children, of which 9 Europeans. 2 deaths were due to diphtheria; 13 from typhus and 2 of enteric fever ; 51 deaths were due to measles and 1 from erysipelas.

div.head: Port and Lighthouses Administration.
div.p: The tender submitted by Messrs. William Allison & Co. of Gracechurch Street, London, on the 23rd April, 1907, has been accepted for the supply of one steel floating sheers required by this Administration. The tender submitted by Mr. F. Erriquez on the 10th May, has been accepted for the supply of 310 cubic metres coping stones (pierre de couronnement) and 330 cubic metres dressed stones (pierre de faille), required by this Administration.

div.head: Khanka Asylum
div.p: The new Asylum at Khanka, which is being constructed by the Government, will cost L.E. 107,000. The site will occupy, including the grounds, about seventy-five feddans. Until this new asylum is finished there will still be some overcrowding at the Abbassieh Asylum, but the want of space there has been partially relieved by increasing the number of beds from 520 to 640. A building which adjoins the Asylum, and which up to the present time has been used by the Egyptian army as a hospital, was vacated last December. It is now being adapted to Asylum requirements. When the work has been completed it will enable 172 more patients to be accommodated.

div.head: THE CROMER MEMORIAL
div.p: CAIRO'S DECISIONS.

Ten days after the meeting which finally decided the question of a public memorial to Lord Cromer had been held, we are favoured with a report of the proceedings. We desire to make a strong protest against the exclusion of the Press from the meetings of a committee which is supposed to represent the Public, and we might point out that by not inviting the Press to attend their meetings the committee are in danger of estranging public sympathy. The Press represents the Public, and were it not for the fact that the appreciation of Lord Cromer's work is so sincere and so great, it is not improbable that the deliberations of the committee would be altogether disregarded by a large portion of the Public. Public opinion can hardly be considered when the Press is excluded, and public interest is most certainly put aside by such exclusion.

At the meeting in question the Ministers and the Advisers were present and the gathering was more than representative : the list of of notabilities is somewhat superfluous here, but the composition of the members of the meeting is a standing proof of the personal nature of the esteem in which our late Minister Plenipotentiary was held, and is confounding to the man (happily in the street) who has sought to discount Lord Cromer's work and the unfortunate reasons which influenced his retirement.

Moustapha Pasha Felmy proposed a vote of thanks to the director of the Khedivial theatre. Mr. Clementi, for the very excellent organisation of the arrangements at the Opera House on the occasion of the manifestation to his Lordship on May 4th, and this well-deserved tribute was received with the unanimous approval it merited.

His Excellency then proceeded to inform the meeting that in reply to the proposal to the Alexandria Committee to join forces it had been agreed that after provision had been made for the Tuberculosis Hospital at Alexandria, as originally decided on by the maritime Capital, the balance should be placed in a general fund at Cairo, after which subscriptions would be obtained in other centres without reference to Alexandria.

After a short discussion it was decided that the amount so accumulated should be administered by the sub-committee appointed at the last meeting with a view to the improvement of the children's dispensaries organised by Lady Cromer in Cairo and the extension of this invaluable work in other towns.

It was further laid down that such subscriptions should be deposited at the National Bank at Alexandria in order to enable Alexandrians to contribute to the general fund as well as to the particular fund of their own city.

So soon as the subcommittee will have received sufficient contribution for the carrying out of the secondary programme, a further general meeting will he held with a view to making a careful study of the question of the carrying out of the present suggestion for the extension of children's dispensaries.

That a reasonable combination has been arrived at is a matter for congratulation, and we might even remark that our recently expressed opinion that each town should have its monument, has been justified, hut we are not fully persuaded that full justice has been done to a most exceptional occasion for the commemoration of the work of Egypt's best friend.

div.head: EGYPT AND THE RADICALS.
div.p: The Radical opinion in regard to Egypt is well exemplified in the following passage from the latest issue of "Truth" :—

That Lord Cromer was a great and able pro-consul no one can dispute. To him it is largely due that Egypt is prosperous and well-governed. His mistake—as it seems to me— has been to consider that provided a country be well governed it is not desirable that its people should have any voice in its government. We obtained the assent of Europe to our exercising sway in Egypt on the distinct pledge that this sway was to lie temporary, and that we should endeavour to teach the Egyptians to manage their own affairs. The latter part ot the undertaking we have not attempted to carry out, and Lord Cromer has not only admitted this, but urged his successor to continue his system. Thus, whilst Egypt has benefitted materially by our rule, the population does not love us, and the number of fairly educated Egyptians who claim the same rights which we ourselves boast of possessing is annually on the increase. This creates for us an unsafe position, and is at variance with all our doctrines in regard to the government of the people by the people. Lord Cromer seems to be of opinion that any Egyptian who claims a voice in the government of his country a graceless and thankless rascal. But should we be ruled even by angels from Paradise, if they were not British citizen ? Should we deem those who rebelled against this angelic rule noisy, blatant demagogues who did not understand what was best for them ? I do not say that we should at once establish in Egypt the degree of self-government that we have at home. But we ought to make some endeavour to train the Egyptians in the principles and habits of self-government and this can only be done by giving them some sort of representive Assembly, with some sort of rights. I trust that Sir Eldon Gorst will adopt this course.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Asiatic Prince with passengers and a general cargo left Malta on the 22nd inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Sunday, the 26th inst.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA QUAY ESTATE.
div.p: TO-DAY'S AUCTION SALE.

This morning ten lots on the new quay estate were put up for auction at the Alexandria Municipality. Although all the lots wore excellently situated, facing the Eastern Harbour and in the neighbourhood of the Kamleli Boulevard, such is the prevailing death of money and lack of confidence, that not a single purchaser put in an appearance except the Khédivial Club at Alexandria, which purchased two lots for the site of its new Club premises. These were numbers 1 and 3 of block XXIV. They comprise respectively 1,491 and 1,309 square pics or a total of 2,800 square pics.
The upset price was L.E. 9 per pic and they were knocked down to the Club for P.T. 1 above this sum. The two lots are in a splendid situation, facing the sea and near the terminus of the Ramleh line.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive has retuned to Montazah from Mariout.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON MILLS.
div.p: At the extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Egyptian Cotton Mills, Limited, which was held in Cairo on Thursday last, Mr. P. Back, the chairman who presided, said many causes hack brought them to their present condition. First there was the initial cause of meeting the mills, all the machinery and requirements, having had to be sent to Cairo from England: secondly, the unfortunate attitude of the Egyptian Government with regard to the imposition of the excise duty. The company was under the impression at the start that this would not be collected. Thirdly, considerable money and time were expended in teaching the natives to spin and weave the cotton, and for a long period the mill has manufacturing goods which could hardly be skid to be up to the requirements of the market. When the native laymen had arrived, and their goods of band a readysale the directors found themselves without capital to carry on their business, ami it wax found necessary to issue First Debentures of collateral security for their hank overdraft, and later on they had to issue. Second Debentures for advances to enable the mill to continue work. The issue of those two lots of Debentures had laid a heavy charge on the profits of their undertaking. The excise duty and the interest on the Debentures had more than anything teen the cause of their financial straits and so long as those charges 7 had to be paid there could be no chance of the mills making a profit. The shortage of working capital had also prevented them from buying their cotton to the best advantage, and this, taken in conjunction with the tact that the price of Egyptian cotton had been abnormally high, had proved their final downfall. The directors had therefore decided that the only course open to them was to wind up. He concluded by moving a formarresolution to wind up the company voluntarily.
Mr. H. S. Spedding seconded the motion, which was irarried with one dissentient.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POTTERY
div.p: It is reported that the Government purchased the site on which is situated pottery factory at Foum el Khalig, near the Helouan Railway at Old Cairo, which was started some 7 years ago by a local syndicate and which has given very satisfactory results. We understand that it is now intended to form a small company with sufficient capital to develop and extend an industry which has been proved a success and for which there is an ample field. It is proposed to introduce into this country also the manufacture of glazed pipes, sanitary and either goods which are now imported from England and France locally under proper European supervision. The saving of freight, packing and breakage alone would show a margin of profit of at least 20 percent. The demand for glazed pipes and similar goods has been rapidly increasing since the completion of the Assouan Dam and must still further increase as soon as the drainage works for Cairo are commenced. Mr. W. P. Rix, late manager of the well-known Doulton Potteries in London, when in Egypt some 2 or 3 years ago, visited the Foum el Khalig works and was of opinion that excellent opportunities existed for considerably developing the local manufacture not only of the description of pottery used by natives but likewise the superior quality of goods in request by European merchants for building and other purposes.

div.head:
AN EGYPTIAN'S PLIGHT
HIS LIFE IN LONDON
div.p: The "Daily Mail" of the 15th inst. tells the following story ;—

Owing to his devotion to his young English wife and his refusal to desert or divorce her, a young Egyptian gentleman named Ghaleb is now starving in London with the woman and his child. On Friday he will have to leave his present lodgings.

Ghaleb's story, as recounted by him to a representative of the "Daily Mail," is one in which romance and poverty are equally blended. The son of an Egyptian gentleman of good standing, who recently held an important position under the Egyptian Government he was sent rather more than two years ago to Birmingham University in order that he might take a commercial degree.

While in Birmingham he lodged with the two daughters of a deceased captain of the Royal Navy, who had falled on evil days, and who had to let lodgings in order to earn a livelihood. Ghaleb fell in love with the younger sister and married her, but, as he was dependent upon an allowance from his father, he determined to keep the marriage secret until he was in a position to earn sufficient to be independent.

The father, however, got to hear of what had taken place, and he told his son that his allowance would be stopped and that he would have nothing more to do with him so long as he remained with his English wife.
The fellow alleges that he was told that if he went to Egypt he could easily get a divorce, but he refused to accept this way out of his difficulties. In course of time a child was born.

For months past the the young Egyptian, himself the son of an English mother, has vainly sought employment. He speaks and writes English, Arabic, French, Italian, and Spanish, and he holds a diploma from the Ecole Superieure de Commercé, of Paris. He is twenty-two years age. He has answered hundreds of advertisements without success

Ghaleb is at present living with his wife and child in one room in a back street in Brixton. The furniture consist of a bed (not paid for), a table, two chairs, and a few cooing utensils. Yesterday morning he pawned his remaining spare shirt and his wife's blouse to buy food.

div.head:
THE NATIVE PRESS
THE VEILED PROTECTORATE
div.p: From "Al-Watan."

The question of Occupation seems to have been settled for all time. According to his will become dangerous and perhaps impossible. Egyptians of all shades have become tired of a Majesty's Government it is to be an indefinite affair. But will the Occupation remain an infinite in the present temporary and undefined state ? This is the queation now predominant in every thinking area and is the subject of many contributions to the Egyptian and European Press. If nothing on earth is absolutely lasting, and if no condition can be permanent, surely the present status of the British Occupation must be changed one day. England cannot remain here for ever on sufferance and her position cannot be left in the present undecided form. The Occupation must either end or become clear and official, without the present entanglements and uncertainty which was probably the root of all trouble during these years.

As already mentioned the question of changing this state of a flairs seems to be in the air now. We are with Mr. Dicey that England should either withdraw or stay with the manner and authority of one who has the right to stay, not the timid and hesitating manner of the guest who has overstayed his welcome and feels the weariness of his host. We do not recommend annexation or an open protectorate ; but we apply for a shift from the untenable position which has been maintained too long. If England has no right to stay here, as the Egyptian fellah is being constantly reminded by these Nationalist papers, the Occupation must come to an end or the propaganda of agitation will grow and the work of Government in Egypt will become dangerous and perhaps impossible.

Egyptians of all shades have become tired of a temporary Occupation which provides means for sedition and disturbance, and they heartily wish to see a powerful administration set here on a permanent footing. Of course, we all prefer a native Government and trust that England will help to make us independent one day. Meanwhile let this temporary arrangement come to an end for nothing comes out of suspense but trouble to all concerned. We are not inviting England to swallow our independence and we hope that our warning will not be misconstrued.

div.head: MEDICINE IN ANCIENT EGYPT.
div.p: There is in evidence in inscriptions and manuscripts that the ancient Egyptian practised medicine and surgery extensively. Probably their practice was based on little knowledge of anatomy. Each physician treated only one of two diseases. The sick were exposed in public places, so that others who had suffered similarly might tell them of helpful remedies. Diseases of the eye were best understood and received both medical and surgical treatment. The most important medical manuscript found in Egypt is the Papyrus Ebers, written 3000 B.C., and discovered in Memphis. Disease, according to the Egyptians, was due to the anger of some deity, the result of the triumph of evil in its struggle with good—an idea which is still very general throughout Africa and Asia, and which at some time has been prevalent in modified forms in almost every race. ("Records of the Past").

div.head:
THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
IMPORTANT MEETING OF BANKERS.
A SYNDICATE TO BE FORMED.
div.p: An important and representative meeting was held yesterday afternoon at Alexandria in order to consider what steps should be taken in order to relieve the existing financial crisis. The managers of the local banks and a large gathering of the heads of the private banking establishments were present. The tone of the meeting was excellent and it was recognised by all present that a decisive scheme should be agreed upon. After a discussion, which showed a keen desire on the part of all present to come to the help of the situation, it was decided to form a syndicate for the purpose of purchasing first-rate Egyptian shares with the object of bringing relief to the existing tension, which, it was affirmed, has been brought about by a great want of confidence and strong bear operations.

The meeting was of opinion that if the banks and capitalists began to purchase first class shares approximately at the current prices on the Alexandria and Cairo Bourses, the result of these operations would be that the confidence of the public would be restored and the solid investor, who has held aloof owing to the tension, would thus be induced to buy. The meeting therefore came to a decision to ask the banks to advance over half a million sterling. This sum is to be guaranteed by first class shares. The margin and the rate of interest are to be within reasonable limits. The great banking establishments, represented by their managers at the meeting, accepted this proposition, which was put forward by the heads of private banking firms but subject to the sanctions of their respective boards of directors. The following banks, subject to the above-mentioned condition, gave their adherence to the scheme and agreed to form part of the syndicate:—

The National Bank of Egypt, Bank of Egypt, Bank of Athens, Banco di Roma, Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio, Comptoir National d'Escompte de Paris Deutsche Orientbank, Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Credit Lyonnais and the Imperial Ottoman Bank. These banks will subscribe in large proportions to the syndicate and the balance of the capital required will be subscribe by the following private linking houses : J. L Menusce Sons, Alexandria, Mosseri and Co., Cairo, C. M. Salvage and Co., Alexandria, Moise Tilche Fils, Alexandria, B. Tilche and Figli, Alexandria, C. G. Zervudachi and sons Alexandria, R. Rolo Figli and Co., Alexandria, Cattaoui Freres and Co., Alexandria, I. M. Cattaoui Fils and Co., Cairo, The Commercial and Estates Company of Egypt Limited, Alexandria, Suarés Frères and Co., Joseph Aghion and Fils, Alexander Sursock, Joseph Sursock and Fils, J. Rolo and Co., Stagni and Figli. These firms are thoroughly representative and embrace the names of the leading capitalists. Each member of the syndicate will be held responsible in proportion to his share in it. The guarantee is considered satisfactory.

Public opinion is unanimous that the result of yesterday afternoon's meeting will be beneficial and should materially contribute to relieve the crisis. After all the first class, coupon-paying Egyptian shares have fallen to such a level that it is well worth while for the seriously-minded investor to seize the present opportunity to enter the market. It is assumed that as soon as buying begins, investors, who have been holding aloof in hopes of taking advantage of a further fall, will come forward. The present crisis has been precipitated by want of confidence, coming as a reaction after a long burst of speculation. This want of confidence has become so ingrained in the opinion of the local public, that everybody, who has any capital to spare has been sitting in it, and the most pesssimistic forebodings have been rife, although the country generally has never been more prosperous.
This morning, as our Bourse bulletin shows, the share market was comparatively speaking quite cheerful as a result of the confidence inspired by yesterday's meeting.
Voici la note qui a dr remise hier matin à sir Eldon Gorst par MM. Adolf Cattaui et Negrin :
Note sur la situation ecs Places du Caire et d'Alexandrie et moyen propose pour y porter remade.

La crise que traversent en ce moment les marchés du Caire et d'Alexandrie est arrivée à un tel degré d'acuité que l'on peut craindre qu'elle n'affecte la -valenr de la propriété immobilièref base de la fortune publique en Egypte.

Cause de la crise : Les causes de cette crise sont faciles à déterminer ; dans un pays en plein développement économique il n'est pas surprenant de voir las affairas prendre une extension trop rapide. C'est une conséquence presque inévitable à laquelle l'Egypte n'a pas échappé. Des Sociétés, en nombre considérable, ne tardèrent pas à se former pour exprimer la richesse du pays dans dans toutes ses branches, et les capitaux disponibles furent bientôt engagés dans les affaires dont la plupart étaient çaines, mais demandaient un certain temps pour produire un rendement rémunérateur.

La spéculation, facteur important du développement financier, s'emparait des titres de ces nouvelles Sociétés et, en escomptant les chances d'avenir, en portait le prix à un taux qui n'avait plus aucun rapport, ni avec le revenu de ces titres, ni avec l'jntérêt payé aux Banques sur leurs avances.

Des événements étrangers à l'Egypte ont également eu une influence fâcheuse sur nos marchés : l'activité industrielle sest réveillée d'une manière intense en Europe et les capitaux ont trouvé facilement à s'employer avantageusement ; la preuve évidente de oç phénomène est la baisse marquée qui s'est produite sur les valeurs d'Etat Pour ne citer que les Consolidés anglais, les cours en sont tombés, dans l'espce des cinq ou six dernières années, de 112 & 85. Les capitalistes européens ont de la sorte sous lu main de* placements rémunérateurs, et il s'en est suivi un renchérissement as*ez accentué de l'argeut Or, l'épargne n'existant pas en Egypte sous forme liquide, c'est par voie d'emprunt que le public a en quelque sorte souscrit à toutes les valeurs qui lui ont été offertes dans oee derniers temps ; tant qua le taux d'intérét était baA, il a pu soutenir les titres achetés, mais dès que le taux a augmenté et qoe la charge de ce chef s'est alourdie, le public a essayé de réaliser le plus rapidement possible pour éviter que le paiement des intérêts n'absorbe le bénéfice probable de la plus value des titres.

Tout le monde sest donc trouvé vendeur en môme temps et les valeurs offertes n'étant en grande partie cotées quaux Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie, il en est résulté un effondrement sur les cours son vent peu justifiés si l'on examine de près la situation financière des sociétés intéressées.

Cette situation a eu imraédiatemqut sa répercussion sur le prix des actions des Sociétés ou Etablissements de premier ordre, tels que la National Bank, le Crédit Foncier, l'Agricole, fa Daïra, la Land Bank etc ; ne pouvant se défaire des titres qui ne trouvaient pas acheteur dans lepays, le public a vendu et vend à tout prix ces valeurs qui sont connues et qui ont un marché ouvert dans les Bourses de 'Europe. Mais la loi inflexible de l'offre et de la demande a de nouveau trouvé son application et les prix cotés aujourd hui sont de 15 ou de 20% au dessous des prix qui se pratiquement il y a 2 ou 3 mois ; comme dans tous les, cas analogues ou est tombé dans l'excès contraire : ainsi aux cours d'aujourd'hui Faction de la National Bank se capitalise à près de 5%, le Crédit Foncier à 5%, la Daïra à 6%, l'Agricole à plus de 5%, la Land Bank à 6%.

Une autre cause est venue augmenter le malaise général ; la valeur de la propriété immobilière a augmenté dans cef derniers temps dans des proportions peutêtre exagérées parvapporp à 1 accroissement de la population, cettropriété passant de main en main à des prix élevés a fait naître un besoin de capitaux importants destinés à couvrir les différences sur les échanges ; tant qué le débouché était ouvert et que l'acheteur n'était en quetoue sorte qu'un intermédiaire qui comptait simplement sur une revente pour sassurer un bénéfice, les choses ont pu se maintenir, mais le jour oh les opérations se sont ralenties, par suite du renchérissement de l'argent et que des acheteurs se sont trouvés dans la nécessité de faire face à leurs engagements, il a fallu faire flèche de tout bois et se défaire de toutes les. valeurs pouvant être réalisées pour réunir des capitaux liquides.

On assiste ainsi à un spectacle caxactéristi que ; rien que par le fait du besoin d'argent liquide toutes les valeurs sont offertes parfois à das prix bien au-dessous de leur valeur intrinsèque, et cette offre produjt un affaissement sur les prix qui obligent les Banques à demander à leurs clients une marge nouvelle en garantie de leurs avances : cette demande, toute justifiée qu'elle puisse paraître, augmente encore le malaise et la méfiance, et précipite davantage la baisse des cours.

Il semble, en examinant froidement la situation, qu'un remède pourrait être trouvé si le marché pouvait compter sur une somme-de un million de livres, par exemple, qui serait mise en circulation sans toutefois être enlevée aux avances actuellement en cours. Les Banques étrangères, dont les affaires sont Alimentées par des tirages à trois mois et qui sont dirigées par des Conseils résidant à l'étranger, ne semblent pas pouvoir êtred'un grand secours dans les circonstances actuelles.

La National Bank peut, peut-être, aider le marché. dans une certaine mesure ; mais les conditions particulières de son organisation lui font une obligation d'avoir des disponibilités immédiates assez importantes, et il ne semble pas qu'il lui-soit possible de les engager dans des affaires qui ne pourront se liquider dans un délai absolument déterminé.

Mais ce qu'elle ne peut faire au moyen de ses ressources propres, la National Bank pourrait le faire si elle avait la certitude que le Gouvernement lni laisserait entre les mains, mettons pendant une anne, les sommes quelle mettrait en circulation.

La National Bank, pour cette nouvelle opération qui serait faite pour le compte du Gouver renement, établirait une liste dés valeurs sérieuses sur lesquelles elle consentirait des avances : les prix actuels et une marge de 20% sont une garantie presque absolue contre tout risque de perte.

Il se peut que les grands travaux d'utilité publique et les dépenses considérables auxquelles ils donnent lieu, absorbent toutes lee disponibilités du Trésor; mais à part de Question qu'il est beaucoup plus facile au Gouvernement qu'à une place déjà si obér de trouverun million de livres à l'heure actuelle, le Ministère des Finances peut réaliser une partie des titres constituant son fond de réserve il trouvera, dans la différence d'iutèrfct entre les plAements qu'il va faire et le toux aotupl une compensation à la perte, qui peut er d'une réalisation qu'il imposerait enjoutd'hei ; et même si une opération de ce genre devait ehfin le compta se traduire par de 1 ou 2% par an sur le voyé, W Gouyeruçment estimera sans dontq sacrifice n'est pas au desssus de ses forces quand il a'agit d'epir un moureat ani funeste.
Le Caire, le 22 Mai 1907

La question financière qui a pris, quelque temps, une tournoie solliciter an premier chef lenet Goret, car tout les progrès dont on pearer la prochaine réalisation dépendent de de prospérité matérielle de la contrée.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Reuter's Agency, in a telegram dated Addis Abeba, May 22, reports that Mr. Klobuwsky has arrived at the Abyssinia Capital, where he was received in great ceremony by the Emperor's orders. The Emperor is absent but is returning specially to confer with Mr. Klobukowsky.

To-day the Marquis of Tullibardine, who was associated with Sir Hector Macdonald in the Sudan campaigns, will inaugurate the magnificent memorial at Dingwall, Rosshire, which is the outcome of an appeal initiated by the Clan Macdonald Society in Glasgow, and responded to from all quarters of the globe. The memorial takes the form of an imposing tower in the old Scottish baronial style of architecture, 100 feet in height and 350 teet above the sea level. It forms a conspicuous landmark, while the view from the topmost balcony embraces half a dozen of the northern counties. The memorial, which was designed by Mr. J. Sandford Kay, of Glasgow, was selected from over 160 competitive plans.
Said Bey Shoucair has been promoted to the post of Director-General of Sudan Accounts at a salary of L.E. 1,500 from January last.

At yesterdays meeting of the Association of Merchandise Brokers at Alexandria, Mr. Alfred Campos pronounced a panegyric on Mr. Michael Sinadino, on the occasion of that gentleman's retirement from the chairmanship of the association.

The Rev. Archimandrite A. Paraschis, having left England on his appointment to the Bishop ric of Patras, the Rev. Archimandrite C. Pagonis, of Alexandria, has arrived in London at 33, Chepstow place, Bayswater.
Messrs. J. and S. Sinadino have subscribed £20 to the Asile Rudolph in memory of the late Sydney Henton Carver.

The many friends of Dr. Sandwith in Egypt will be interested in the following paragraph from the "Pall Mall Gazette" :- Dr. Fleming Mant Sandwith, who has inaugurated his Gresham Professorship of Medicine by the prescribed lecture, is the sort of man whom Sir Thomas, the founder of the Royal Exchange, and also of those professorial allocutions would have quite approved of. Adventures were for the adventurous "King's merchant," as they have been for the Khedive's Consultant, and the Senior Physician I. Y. at Pretoria. He is a soldier's son, and the husband of his cousin, Sandwith of Kars'daughter. As ambulance surgeon in the Turco-Russian war he was through the fight in the Shipka Pass ; and he was on Valentine Baker Pasha's staff when, on the New Year's Day of 1878, that born general, handling the three arms together for the first time, fought his memorable rearguard action in the retreat across the Rhodope Mountain.
Last night Mrs. Reinsperger, the wife of the popular manager of the New Khédivial Hotel at Alexandria, gave birth to a son. The mother and child are doing well.

div.head: ANNUAIRE DIDOT-BOTTIN.
div.p: Nous avôns reçu la visite de M. Alfred Burke- Honan, Inspecteur Général de la Société anonyme de l'Annuaire Didot-Bottin, membre du Syndicat de la Presse Coloniale.

L'édition du Didot-Bottin de 1907 a fait de progrès notables vu surtout qu'elle est augmentée d'un volume. La partie de l'ouvrage regardant Paris ayant été divisée en deux tomes, ceci sans augmenter nullement le prix.

Burke-Honan recommande d'une façon toute spéciale une publicité dans le "Guide International" inclus dans le tome II de "Paris." C'est en quelque sorte le livre d'or de la Banque, et de l'Industrie. Cette publicité limitée, bien que d'un tarif actuellement fort réduit, se fait en pages entières sans division et peut assurer à ses bénéficiaires un renvoi dans toutes les villes du monde ou ils ont des intérêts.
Le "Bottin" sera toujours consulté en Egypte aux Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie, Chambres de Commerce Françaises et Etrangères, Halls des banques, grands établissements, etc,, etc.
Pour tous renseignements s'adresser à Monsieur A. Burke-Honan, Hôtel Windsor, Alexandrie, dans le courant du mois de Mai ou à son représentant M. Georges Adib, 3, Rue Stamboul, Alexandrie.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: (Aujourd hui à midi et demie).
Le marché est meilleur et présente un peu plus d'animation.

Les cours sont en hausse par suite de gros achats effectués pour le compte de capitalistes sérieux. La National reprend 3/4 de livre à 22 11 16, l'Agricole 1/8 à 8 3/8, la Sait ami Soda 6 pence à 18/6, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien 1/8 à 5 1.4 et l'Union Foncière 1/16 à 5 1/8.

Par contre la Banque d'Orient retrograde à 122 francs, l'obligation ancienne du Crédit Foncier à 317 francs et la nouvelle à 266 francs. Les Eaux du Caire continuent à baisser à fr. 113 Faction ordinaire et fr. 225 la part de jouissance. Les valeurs égyptiennes sont en reprise sur les marchés européens.
Ici, la tendance est bonne.

L'Assemblée Générale ordinaire de la "Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oases Co." a été tenue avant-hier. La nomination de MM. A. Curphey et Jacoub Pacha Artin en qualité d'Administratéurs a été ratifiée. L'Assemblée générale extraordinaire, qui a eu lieu aussitôt après, a approuvé la convention pass'e avec le gouvernement relative à la construction d'habitations à bon marché pour employés de l'Etat.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny

div.p: Le Caire, Mercredi 22 Mai 1907.
Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a baissé hier de 1/8 à 3 1/8.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté in varié à 85, do même que l'Unifiée à 100. La National Bank a perdu non moins de £ 1 5/8 à 21 3/4, sur des ordres do venté provenant, parait il, d'Egypte. L'Agricole a, iTautrepart, laissé 3/8 à 8 1,4 et la Delta Light 1/4 à 9 3/4. La Daïra Sanieh est demeurée inchangée à l5.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a baissé de 11 francs à 711. La Banque d'Athènes s'est maintenue à 128.

Ici, le marché les valeurs ne s'est pas trop laissé impressionner par la fort mauvaise tenue des valeurs égyptiennes à Londres et à Paris. On était bien en droit de s'attendre à.un commencement de panique. Or, il faut rendre cette justice à notre marché qu r il a montre beaucoup de sang froid et «le résistance. Cette attitude courageuse est due,il est vrai, en grande partie, aux rumeurs de plus en plus persistantes suivant lesquelles les Banques se servent finalement déterminées, dans une vue dlintérêt gé néral, à accorder les facilités qu'on leur avait vainement demandées il y a en mois.
En attendant, la National Bank, que nous avions laissée hier à 22 5/8, a fechi-à 21 15/16. L'Agricole n'a perdu que 1/8 à 8 3/16.
Le Crédit Foncier a clôturé a 710, soit en perte de 10 francs ; l'obligation à lots ancienne a faibli à 318.
La New Egyptian a rétrogradé à 17 sh. 3.

Le restant de la cote figure invarié sur le tableau officiel de la Corporation des agents de change, bien que des transactions aient été ouvertement pratiquées à divers prix en dessous (en pleine corbeille) sur la plupart des titres, même sur ceux dont les coin's étaient en quelque sorte protégés par les cours de compensa tion forcés fixés le 22 Avril dernier. Il en est, d'ailleurs, de même à Alexandrie, et ce depuis plusieurs jours.
Aussi bien, le Comité de la Corporation tiendra seance cet après-midi pour examiner la question de savoir s'il ne serait pas opportun do laisser le marché entièrement libre.
On nous écrit d'Alexandrie à la date d'hier-:

De même qu'au Caire, l'attention générale est concentrée sur la passe difficile que traverse le marché des valeurs, ainsi que celui des cotons. Le sujet est, certes, vivement intéres saut, mais beaucoup d'hommes d'affaires déplorent le ton sinistre des articles publié par divers journaux, ton qui n'est pas appelé à inspirer confiance aux capitaux européens, à raffermir le crédit égyptien à l'étranger et, partant, à enrayer la baisse.

En attendant, la rumeur que deux importantes maisons de commerce notre place, fortement engagées dans les grosses valeurs, ont dû suspendre leurs paiements, a déterminé ce matin une nouvelle dépression en Bourse, notamment sur la National Bank, l'Agricolo et la Béhéra.
Parlant de l'état général du marché, le " Phare d'Alexandrie " de cet après-midi s'ex- prime ain-i :

" Lorsquil a été résolu d'établir les cours forcés à la Bourse, nous avons émis des doutes sur l'opportunité et l'utilité de cette mesure, exprimant la crainte qu'elle aggravât une si tuation déjà difficile on prolongeant une situation malasisee et en precipitant la basisse. L'evenement justifie nos previsions. Aussi l'opinion que mieux vaudrait rendre au marche la liberte gagne t-elle chaque jour du terrain. Elle est maintenant partagee par un grand nombre, si ce n'est par la majorite, des courtiers. Il faut, pour que la Bourse se remette, que la liquidation necessaire se fasse. Tous les moyens artificiels adoptes dans le but illusoire de remediera la crise ne font que la prolonger."

La "Reforme" declare egalement qu'on se plaint de la continuation de l'interdiction de negocier les valeurs a leurs cours veritables. La measur etait bonne jusqu'a la liquidation fin Avril ; elle est franchement mauvaise depuis lors.

D'apres "The Egyptian Gazette" quelques chiffres suddisent a montrer que la crise financiere actuelle se confine simplement aux Bourses d'Alexandrie et du Caire. Ainsi les recettes des chemins de fer de l'Etat presentent une augmentation de 20% sur celles de l'annee derniere ; les recettes des douanes indiquent egalement l'etat prospere du pays : elles sont en surcroit de 35%. Il en est de meme des Societes privees de transport et autres, ce qui prouve que le pays n'est pas atteint par les difficultes de la speculation.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du Public, que les offres faites le 10 Mai courant, pour l'achat de 561 vieilles portes et fenêtres n'ayant pas été satisfaisantes, l'Administration a décilé de les remettre eu adjudication ainsi que quinze à vingt tonnes environ de vieux bois. En conséquence, il sera procédé le Mercredi vingt neuf Mai courant, à neuf heures du matin, à la vente aux enchères publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, aux Magasins de Gabbary à Alexandrie, du matériel cidessus spécifié provenant des anciens logements du personnel dernièrement démolis à Gabal Zeitoun. Les portes et fenêtres se trouvent à Gabal-Zeitoun. près de la station de Gabbary, où on peut les examiner chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p.m. lies dimanches et jours fériés exceptés.

On peut prendre connaissance des conditions de vente et de la liste de ce matériel au bureau Central des Magasins Généraux à Boulac (Caire) et an bureau de M. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary à Alexandrie, tous les jours de neuf heures du matin à midi. Les dimanches et jours fériés exceptas.

Pour être admis à concourir, le soumissionnaire «levra, au préalable, verser une somme de LE. 10 (Livres Egyptiennes dix) a titre de dévalt provisoire. Le soumissionnaire dédaré adjudicataire devra jairfaire cette somme jusqu'à concurrence du 10% (dix pour cent) du montant de l'offre agréée et enlèvera à ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjugés «laiLs un délai de vingt-cinq jours à compter de la date de l'avis d'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres pourront être faites sur jiapier timbré «le trente millièmes, si l'intéressé ne peut pas assister aux enchères, et dans ce cas la soumission ainsi que le reçu du versement du dépôt provisoire, seront adressés par la Poste sous pli recommandé à :—
Monsieur l'Inspecteur des Magasins des Chemins «le fer de l'Etat à Gabbary (Alexandrie)
et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la «ascription suivante :
"Offre our achat de vieux Lus, j'dortes et fenêtres."
Toute off re faite ou déposée ultérieurement au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.
L'Adininistration ne s'engage jms à accepter les prix les plus élèvé ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le driot de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 20 Mai 1907. 30319-2-1

div.head:
IRISH BILL REJECTION.
LIBERAL DISAPOINTMENT.
THE UNIONISTS REJOICE.

div.p: The decision of the Dublin Convention is regarded by Radical and Unionist papers alike as a serious blow to the Government generally, it is expected that the bill will be dropped. The "Daily News" says that the shadow of failure has already fallen on the hopes of Liberalism. If yesterday's work leads to embitterment between the Liberals and the Irish the next election will witness neither the destruction of the Lords' veto nor the triumph of democracy. (Reuter)

The newspapers rejoice at the result of the vote taken at the convention. The Unionists say that the English people have absolutely no excuse for pretending not to understand the real nature of the Nationalist claim, while the Home Rulers declare that no other decision could have been arrived at consistent with the unimpaired existence of the movement for complete self government will recast its plan for grappling with the problem. (Reuter)

div.head:
DAMAGE AT MANILA.
DESTRUCTIVE TIDAL WAVE.

div.p: A hurricane and tidal waves swept the Caroline Islands on the 30th April : great damage was done : 200 natives perished. (R.)

div.head:
THE KILBURN'S CREW.
ATTACKED BY BEDOUINS.

div.p: The crew of the steamer Kilburn, which went Ashore at Kamaran on the Western Coast of Arabia on the 27th April, landed but they were driven off by a Bedouin tribe. They are in need of the protection of a gunboat. (R.)

div.head:
CRICKET RESULTS.
TROTT CREATES WORLDS RECORD.

div.p: Kent beat Sussex by an innings and 243 runs. The South Africans beat Leicester by 98 runs. Notts Wat Surrey by 202 runs. Essex beat Gloucestershire by is runs. The match between Lancashire and Yorkshire was drawn. Warwickshire heat Worcestershire by and innings and 8 runs. Middlesex beat Somerset by 166 runs. Mr. Trott performed the hat trick twice in one innings, taking the 3rd, 4th, 5th, and 6th wickets in succession and the the last 3, thus constituting the world's record. (Reuter)

The white labourers of 37 Rand mines have gone on strike : the managements are recruiting rural Roers to replace them. 7 Natal natives have been convicted of the murder of a white man during the rising and have been senteneed to death. (Reuter)
Heavy seas are preventing tugs from approaching the Chanzy. The vessel is seriously damaged forward. The stern is awash.(Reuter)
Queen Alexandra has arrived incognito from Naples. (Havas)
M. Caillaux will propose at to-morrow's sitting of the Chamber a law to remedy the wine growing crisis. (Havas)

div.head: The Money Market.
div.p: The policy of the Bank in keeping up its rate is enabling the bankers generally to charge comparatively high rates for money, and on the Stock Exchange 4 1/2 to 5 per cent, is quite a common quotation, although the ordinary hankers are allowing on deposits no more than 3 to 3 1/2 per cent. They should therefore be making large profits at the expense of their customers. The objection to this is that the cheap rate of money is not really effective, and it is thought not improbable that the Bank directors will have to reduce the official minimum at their next meeting.

The maturing of bills held by the Bank, and Whitsuntide holiday requirements have been responsible for a reduction of no less than £2,375,000 in "other" deposits this week, and £636,006 in the stock of coin and bullion. The efflux abroad amounted to only £17,000. On the other hand, the note circulation contracted by £148,000, so that the fall in the reserve is less than half-a-million—£487,000. Consequent on the reduction in the total deposits being on a heavier scale than the depletion of the reserve, the "Proportion" is slightly higher on the week at 46 7/8 per cent. Last year the reserve was £21,387,000 and the proportion a little under 41 1/2 percent. This week the reserve is £24,590,000.
To-day three months' Bank paper has been taken frequently at 3 3/16 per cent.

div.head: The Stock Markets.
div.p: It is with a distinct sense of relief that members of the Stock Exchange welcome the Whitsuntide holidays. The tone of listlessness which has been consequent on the paucity of business has of late become almost painful, and the hope is entertained that the short holiday may do something to stimulate the interest of the investing public in stocks and shares. It will, at least, help to relieve the humdrum monotony of the present day brokers' existence.

This week markets have been even quieter than usual. With the exception of one or two bright spots, idleness has been the ruling feature, and not a few members, realising the uselessness of expecting an improvement this side of Whitsuntide, commenced their holiday two or three days ago.

The failure of an old and hitherto highly respected firm of city solicitors, whose liabilities are said to he about £100,000, has produced forced selling of stocks, and this has prevented any recovery that might have been anticipated. It is understood that the firm had a considerable number of clients in Egypt.

div.head: Consols.
div.p: The gilt-edged market has been very helpless, and at one time Consols were as low as 84 5/8. Yesterday, however, the market was much firmer, and at the close Consols showed a rise of 3/16 to 85 for the account. They have kept steady to-day, and close at 85.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: Foreigners have been a dull market throughout. The demand for Japanese issues which followed the announcement of the Franco- Japanese treaty has eased off, and movements of the stocks have been few and somewhat irregular. Russians were very weak yesterday, the last issue shedding 1/2 to 83 3/4, and the Fours 3/4 to 74 3/4. To- day the Fives close at 84 and the Fours at 74 3/4.

div.head: Home Rails.
div.p: The stocks of the home railways have never been more depressed than during this week, and the constant declines in values are the despair of holders. This fact, however, causes the trade union agitators no concern, and they pursue their demands for higher wages and shorter hours for the employés with a reckless disregard of the interests of the shareholders. They certainly could not have chosen a better time than the present to further embarass the companies, and their latest ultimatum, which, among other demands, includes increases of wages amounting annually to over £7,000,000 shows the unreasonableness of their attitude. In support of their claims mass meetings of railwaymen were held in London and the chief provincial towns last Sunday, and very bombastic speeches were made. The effect of all this upon railway shares may well be imagined. There was a bear raid in the market on the first two days of the week, and prices were forced down all-round. As an instance, it may be mentioned that in the two days Brighton "A" lost 4 1/2 points and the Ordinary 4.

There has, fortunately, since been a better tone prevailing as the result of bear closing, and the improvement in Consols, and yesterday advances of 1/8 to 1/2 were general. A number of buyers were attracted by the low prices. To-day the market has been very firm. North Eastern has advanced 1. Great Eastern ans South Eastern Deferred were 3/4.

div.head: Americans.
div.p: The American market has been very idle, and for the most part the movements have been adverse. An adverse influence has been the publication of the report of the lawyers to the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

Yesterday the market opened with a firm appearance, but soon slipped away, and closed at nearly the lowest figures touched. Unions which had been up to 149 went back to 147 3/4, finishing rather better at 148 1/8, a fall of 2 5/8 on the day. Aitchinson dropped 1 1/4 to 92 1/8. Chesapeake and Ohio at the close were 2 lower at 38 1/4.
After a weak ripening this morning, the tone is now firmer. Unions have advanced 3/4, and Denver Canadian railways are steady. Canadian Pacific has advanced, 1 3/4, and Grand Trunk Ordinary 7/8.

div.head: Egyptians.
div.p: Egyptians have again been a quiet market, but there is a nice business still doing in the better class of shares. National Bank of Egypt have kept fairly firm for some days at 23 5/8-7/8, but fell on Wednesday to 23, 9/l6. Yesterday they changed hands as low as 23 3/8. They leave off to-day at 23 1/4. Agricultural Bank have fallen in sympathy to 8, 9/l6, although a good many shares have been taken off the market at 8, 11/16 and 8 5/8. The new issue of 3 1/2%. Guaranteed Bonds are quoted 1/2 discount to par, and the old 3 1/2% bonds are still about 86-8. Agricultural Bank Preference are dull at 9 1/4-1/2.

Delta Preference Bearer are down to 10 and Delta Land and investment are nominally 2 1/8-3/8. Comptoir Financier are a laid market at 4 3/8-5/8, and Egyptian Estates are once more down to 1 3/8-1/2. The Deferred are quoted 12-14, but there are only sellers about. Daira Sanieh have been dealt in at 15 1/4, closing sellers at this price. Corporation of Western Egypt keep steady at and Egyptian Markets at 1, 5/16, Salt and Soda are 1. New Egyptian have been offered down, and close 7/8-1 ex dividend. Union Foncière are 5 1/4-1/2, and Land Bank of Egypt 8. There is no business doing in the lower priced shares and the quotations are quite nominal.

div.head: Mining.
div.p: The South African section is quite flat, and there is an absolute lack of interest, in these shares. The announcement that the repatriation of the first two batches of Chinese whose contracts are expiring will take place next month, coining on the top of the present labour strike on the Rand, has been anything but a cheering influence considering the already depressed state of the market.
Shares are very quiet to-day and there is no feature of interest.
The Egyptian section is also lifeless, and the shares have scarcely moved since our last. Nile Valleys remain about 1/6.

div.head: DISCOVERIES IN EGYPT.
EXCAVAVATIONS IN 1907.
div.p: A few days ago we gave a short summary of Professor Flinders Petrie's account of the excavations in 1907 of the British School and of the Egyptian Research Account.
The following further statements, in addition to that already published by us, were made by the Professor :—

The first month, he observed, in the last season was spent at Gizeh, and the subsequent four months in the upper country in the region of Assiut. The results represented the first, and, to some extent, the second and third dynasties, and also the period from the ninth to the 12th dynasties. In the first month 49 graves were found—the Royal tombs of Abydos. One tomb was evidently of a Royal personage, though not necessarily a King.

There was a slate palette for painting, the first example hitherto found. Wands were also discovered, with elaborate ivory carving and knives of the first dynasty, and a good deal of panelling in a tomb which formed the centre of a number of smaller graves The second dynasty work had seen mostly destroyed by the 26th dynasty ; but in these comparatively modern tombs had been unearthed stone vases of the earlier age. They found also objects of quartz and cornelian, a long slab, lft by 2in., made of highly worked flint with a sharp polished edge. This had seen left at the museum at Cairo, though Professor Maspero had been most kind and liberal in allowing the removal of some of the remains.

There was, however, not much more to be expected from this district, and only one new site had been explored, and work previously begun on two others had been continued. Of the fifth dynasty five tombs with inscribed lintels and a statuette of limestone had been discovered. In the same place had been found a Ptolemaic cemetery of the 26th dynasty. There were many poor burials also, and Professor Karl Pearson bad in hand the examination of about 1,600 skulls. At Assiut, the site of the Jater months' labour, a large cemetery overwhelmed with a wash of gravel had been found, and hundreds of tombs from the sixth to the 12th dynasty. After the sixth dynasty trays were discovered, which were miniature representations of houses with tanks, and imitation offerings—cakes and other things- for the dead. They were able here also to trace the development of the Egyptian house from the remains found. Sections were shown on the screen of these houses, which in some cases were of two storeys. One was of an elaborate character with a stairway and clinmbers behind. The couch was below for the sake of coolness. The whole elevation of an Egyptian house was clearly traceable with staircases and floorings.The first essential of a house in Egypt was the poetic which, in fact, in the earliest stage constituted the house, and it was copied from the temple, which was of course, regarded as the god's house. Among the objects was the head of a fine coffin of the early 12th dynasty, covered with gold foil ; another in the same shrouded in somewhat silver foil, of which he had not previously met with an instance. The practice of having a cartonnage, starting with the 12th dynasty, appeared to have died out and to have been revived after 3,000 years. There were four or five untouched tombs, probably of stewards or other great, officials. They were hewn out ot the rock and of vast size, the explanation of which prolwbly was that the tomb also served as a quarry for the material for house building. One fine figure with diaper work was disclosed in a body ootfin, and among other objects were boats with masts, oars, and cabins. One tomb was the finest he had come across for a long time, and in it were five statuettes of good quality and workmanship, and in another was a black greenish figure, 15in. high, which was happily, to be brought to England. All this work was ascribable to the 12th dynasty. A later tomb—of the 19th dynasty—was of special interest, as in it was found the first authenticated representation of a camel, though there was evidence from the earliest times of the existence and use of that animal. Remains were also discovered, in this fruitful season, of the later dynasties.

div.head: MACMILLIAN'S COLONIAL LIBRARY.
div.p: The latest addition to that excellent series, known as Macmillan's Colonial Library, is a tale of pithecananthropic man by "Jack London". It is entitled "Before Adam" and deserves to be read as an interesting attempt to portray the conditions of life in the far off days of the Mid- Pleistocene epoch.

div.head: DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.
div.p: Frightened into St. Vitus'
Sheffield Child's Pathetic History
A Twiching Victim of Her Nerves.
Gradually Wasting Away.
One of the Worst Cases Known.
The Pride of Her Mother To-day.
Cured by
DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.

"You would hardly credit what that poor child has gone through," observed Mrs. Emma Rhodes, of 77, John-strect, Sheffield, as she pointed to a bright little girl of ten years who was playing at hall. "Children nowadays," said Mrs. Rhodes, "are all nerves, and full of excitement. Even 'at play their nerves are at high tension over the results of games. But let me explain how my little daughter was marvellously cured of St Vitus' Dance by Dr. Williams' Pink Pink Pills for Pale People. Well, exactly four years ago Emmie had a fright which shattered her nerves. She lost all interest in her childish amusements, and went about as if stunned. There was a frightened expression on her face, her eyes became fixed, and she had a vacant look. Without warning she began to tremble from head to foot, her fingers twitched, and her eves opened and closed with lightning rapidity. I began to have grave fears about her mental condition. Her arms went like clockwork, and she was constantly shifting her legs and feet. Her actions were nervous and rapid ; the least sound caused her to jump, and she could not fix her eyes on any object without shaking and shivering all over. Her speech was so affected that she could only lisp, and every effort to sneak produced a twitching of the mouth.

"This state developed so rapidly that I consulted a doctor, who confirmed our fears. She was suffering from St. Vitus' Dance. Medicine of all sorts was given her, still she did not mend. If she took any food it was vomited immediately ; even milk and liquid nourishment was rejected. Cold perspiratious would break out, and when put to bed the child turned and jumped until the bed shook. For weeks she had no real restful sleep. In the morning she complained of pains in the head, chest, and sides. Her little face became drawn and haggard, and she gradually dwindled away until she became a merè skeleton of a child. For over two months she had to lie in bed ; St. Vitus' Dance had played such havoc with her nerves that she was left a shattered wreck, with death staring us in the face. Her ease was pronounced one of the worst ever known. Through sitting up night and day I felt my own strength giving way. I was on the verge of despair when I accented the advice ot a friend and secured Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People.

After my child had taken the contents of two boxes her nerves showed signs of bracing up. She slept more peacefully, and the nervous twitchings decreased. Her appetite improved so that she could actually eat solid food. I could see an improvement and continued the pills. When she began on the third box her blood began to circulate, and once when my back was turned she got out of bed. 'Mother,' she cried ' I want my toys !' When she got her playthings her face lit up with a new joy. She put on flesh quickly, and her strength began to built up again. So strong and healthy was she that she even went to school and made rapid progress with her lessons. Look at her now and see how strong and healthy she is. I always regret that I did not give her Dr. Williams' Pink Pills at the start, which would have saved our terrible anxiety." Red, Rich Blood—that is the real reason of the grvnt success achieved by Dr. William's Pink Pills, which actually make new blood and so cure all the diseases that arise from weak blood or lack of blood. These pills have cured repeatedly Anaemia, Indigestion, Influenza's After-Effects, Eczema, Rheumatism, St Vitus' Dance, Sciatica, Neuralgia, Paralysis : also the ailments that afflict women only. Only the genuine pills, those labelled in full, Dr.,Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People, effect these cures. Of all dealers, send 2s. 9d. for one box, or 13s. 9d. for boxes direct to the British Depot, 46, Ho'orn-viaduct, London. Substitutes are useless. Sold by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 18 the box and P.T. 70 for six boxes.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le 21 Mai 1907 de 9 h. a.m. a 1 h. p.m. la Municipalite procedera a le vente aux encheres publiques pres du fort No. 20 de Kom el Chougafa El Barrani d'uce quantite de 1,000 metres cubes environ de pierres ainsi que d'une quantife de vieux bois et fers provenant de la demolition du dit fort.
Ces pierres sont divisees en lots de 20 a 100 m. 3.

Les scheteurs devront payer le droit d'enchere de 1 % et deposer le 10 % de la valeur de la marchandise achetee au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement integral a la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjundicaton.

Ils auront a supporter les droits de carrire au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres achetees dan un delai de dix (10) jours sons peine de folle enchere pour compte de l'adjudicataire et sous parte du depot de 10 %
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 13 Mai 1907.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA WATER COMPANY LTD.
div.p: Avis est donné par la présente qu'une Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire de la Compagnie aura lieu au Bureau de la Compagnie à Alexandrie le 11 Juin 1907 à 4 heures et demie de l'après-midi, pour approuver les résolutions suivantes :
1. L'augmentation du capital de la Compagnie par la création de 20,000 nouvelles actions de £5 nominalo chacune, exclusivement offertes aux actionnaires.
2. De donner pouvoirs au Conseil d'Administration d'emettre ces actions, en totalité ou en partie, au moment et au prix qu'il jugera opportun dans l'interét de la Compagnie.
Cette Assemblée aura lieu a la suite de l'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire.

Pour assister ou se faire représenter à cette Assemblée, MM. les propriétaires d'actions au porteur sont informés que, conformément aux Statuts, leurs titres doivent être déposés a l'Anglo Egyptian Bank Ltd., à Alexandrie, au moins trois jours francs, avant l'Assemblée, ou chez Messr. Barclay & Company Ltd. 1, Pali Mail East, London, S.W., a Londres, 14 jours francs, avant l'Assemblée.
Par ordre du Conseil d'Administration,
H. R. C. BLAGDEN.
30288-4-2 Directeur.

div.head: Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company Limited.
div.p: A V I S

L'Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Cy Ltd a l'honneur d'informer le Public, que par suite de l'établissement d'un service spécial entre Alexandrie et Ibrahimieh, les changements suivants seront apportés, à partir du 25 Mai courant, dans la marche des trains sur ses réseaux :

lo.— Les trains de l'ancienne ligne Alexandrie Bulkeley Bacos San Stefano, ne s'arrêteront plus aux Haltes de Camp de César et Sporting Club, cette dernière devant être desservie par les trains du Palais.
2o.—Les trains du Palais no s'arrêteront plus à la Halte Camp do César ni à la Station Ibrahimieh, mais desserviront la Halte Sporting Club.
Les voyageurs de l'ancienne ligne de ou pour la Halte Sporting Club devront changer de train à Sidi-Gaber ou a Bulkeley, suivant leur convenance.
Alexandrie le 22 Mai 1907.
